	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	22
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>

<FONT SIZE="1">

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX">

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	assurance that the indemnity from Motorola Mobility will be sufficient to protect us against the full amount of such liabilities, or that Motorola Mobility will be able to fully satisfy its
	indemnification obligations, even if the pending acquisition by Google is completed. Third-parties could also seek to hold us responsible for any of the liabilities that Motorola Mobility has agreed to assume. Even if we ultimately succeed in
	recovering from Motorola Mobility any amounts for which we are held liable, we may be temporarily required to bear these losses ourselves. In addition, indemnities that we may be required to provide Motorola Mobility are not subject to any cap, may
	be significant and could negatively impact our business. Each of these risks could negatively affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. For more detailed information, see the Amended and Restated Master Separation and
	Distribution Agreement which was filed as an exhibit to our Form&nbsp;10-Q for the third quarter 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	A change of control of or
	bankruptcy of Motorola Mobility could result in an incompatible third-party owning the Motorola Marks or the loss of certain rights, including the license.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Since Motorola Mobility owns the Motorola Marks, in the event Motorola Mobility is acquired, the acquiring entity would gain control of the Motorola Marks. If the acquisition by Google is completed, the
	Motorola Marks will be controlled by Google. In the event of a liquidation of Motorola Mobility or the then owner of the Motorola Marks, it is possible that a bankruptcy court would permit the Motorola Marks to be assigned to a third-party. While
	our right to use the Motorola Marks under our license should continue in our specified field of use in such situations, it is possible that we could be party to a license arrangement with a third-party whose interests are incompatible with ours,
	thereby potentially making the license arrangement difficult to administer, and increasing the costs and risks associated with sharing the Motorola Marks. In addition, there is a risk that, in the event of a bankruptcy of Motorola Mobility or the
	then owner of the Motorola Marks, Motorola Mobility, the then owner or its bankruptcy trustee may attempt to reject the license, or a bankruptcy court may refuse to uphold the license or certain of its terms. Such a loss could negatively affect our
	business, results of operations and financial condition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	We contributed a significant portfolio of intellectual property rights, including
	patents, to Motorola Mobility and we are unable to leverage these intellectual property rights as we did prior to the distribution of Motorola Mobility.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We contributed approximately 17,200 granted patents and approximately 8,000 pending patent applications worldwide to Motorola Mobility in connection with the distribution. Although we have a perpetual,
	royalty free license to these patents and other intellectual property rights, we no longer own them. As a result we are unable to leverage these intellectual property rights for purposes of generating licensing revenue or entering into favorable
	licensing arrangements with third parties. As a result we may incur increased license fees or litigation costs. Although we cannot predict the extent of such unanticipated costs, it is possible such costs could negatively impact our financial
	results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Completion of the distribution of Motorola Mobility may not enhance long-term shareholder value.
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We completed the distribution of Motorola Mobility on January&nbsp;4, 2011. At the time of this distribution, our board and management
	team, after consultation with independent financial and legal advisors, believed that the distribution of Motorola Mobility as planned would enhance long-term shareholder value. There can be no assurance, however, that the combined value of our
	common stock and the common stock of Motorola Mobility will equal or exceed what the value of our common stock would have been in the absence of the distribution in the long term, particularly if the acquisition of Motorola Mobility by Google is not
	completed. The combined value of the common stock of the two companies could be lower than anticipated for a variety of reasons, including, among others, the inability of Motorola Mobility to complete its acquisition by Google or to compete
	effectively as an independent company.
</FONT>
</P>

	Item&nbsp;2: Properties
</B>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Motorola Solutions&#146; principal executive offices are located at 1303 East Algonquin Road,
	Schaumburg, Illinois 60196. Motorola Solutions also operates manufacturing facilities and sales offices in other U.S. locations and in many other countries.
</FONT>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2011, we owned 19 facilities (manufacturing, sales, service and
	office), 15 of which were located in the Americas Region (USA, Canada, Mexico, Central and South America) and 4 of which were located in other countries. As of December&nbsp;31, 2011, the Company leased 193 facilities, 91 of which were located in
	the Americas Region and 102 of which were located in other countries. As of December&nbsp;31, 2011, we primarily utilized 6 major facilities for the manufacturing and distribution of our products, and these facilities were located in: Penang,
	Malaysia; Reynosa, Mexico; McAllen, Texas; Schaumburg, Illinois; Berlin, Germany; and Suzhou, China.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Motorola Solutions
	generally considers the productive capacity of the plants operated by each of our business segments to be adequate and sufficient for the requirements of each business group. The extent of utilization of such manufacturing facilities varies from
	plant to plant and from time to time during the year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2011, a substantial portion of our products were manufactured in our
	own facilities in Mexico and Malaysia. A portion of our manufacturing is done by a small number of non-affiliated electronics manufacturing suppliers and distribution and logistics services providers, most of which are outside the United States. We
	rely on these third-party providers in order to enhance our ability to lower costs and deliver products that meet consumer demands. If manufacturing in our own facilities, or by third-parties who manufacture and assemble approximately 20% of our
	products were disrupted, our overall productive capacity could be significantly reduced.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_PROPERTIES>
<EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<A NAME="FIS_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
<A NAME="D280303D10K_HTM_TOC280303_20">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;3: Legal
	Proceedings
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The proceedings referenced below refer to Motorola, Inc., our former name, and we have not changed the court
	descriptions to refer to Motorola Solutions, Inc.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Silverman Federal Securities Class Action Case
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A purported class action lawsuit on behalf of the purchasers of Motorola securities between July&nbsp;19, 2006 and January&nbsp;5, 2007,
<I>
	Silverman v. Motorola,&nbsp;Inc., et al
</I>
	., was filed against the Company and certain current and former officers and directors of the Company on August&nbsp;9, 2007, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois.
	The complaint alleges violations of Section&nbsp;10(b) and Rule&nbsp;10b-5 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as well as, in the case of the individual defendants, the control person provisions of the Securities Exchange Act. The factual
	assertions in the complaint consist primarily of the allegation that the defendants knowingly made incorrect statements concerning Motorola&#146;s projected revenues for the third and fourth quarter of 2006. The complaint seeks unspecified damages
	and other relief relating to the purported inflation in the price of Motorola shares during the class period. An amended complaint was filed December&nbsp;20, 2007, and Motorola moved to dismiss that complaint in February 2008. On September&nbsp;24,
	2008, the district court granted this motion in part to dismiss Section&nbsp;10(b) claims as to two individuals and certain claims related to forward looking statements, among other things, and denied the motion in part. On August&nbsp;25, 2009, the
	district court granted plaintiff&#146;s motion for class certification. On March&nbsp;10, 2010, the district court granted plaintiffs motion to file&nbsp;a second amended complaint which adds allegations concerning Motorola&#146;s accounting and
	disclosures for certain transactions entered into in the third quarter of 2006. On February&nbsp;16, 2011, the district court granted summary judgment to dismiss the remaining claims as to two individual defendants and the Section&nbsp;10(b) claim
	as to a third individual, and denied the motion in part. On March&nbsp;21, 2011, Motorola filed a motion for summary judgment on the remaining claims against the Company and other individual defendants. On July&nbsp;25, 2011, the district court
	denied the motion for summary judgment. On February&nbsp;1, 2012, the parties in the
<I>
	Silverman
</I>
	litigation signed a settlement agreement to resolve all claims in that case.&nbsp;The agreement has been submitted to the Court and is subject to
	preliminary and final approval.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	St.&nbsp;Lucie County Fire District Firefighters&#146; Pension Trust Fund Securities Class Action Case
	and Related Derivative Matter
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A purported class action lawsuit,
<I>
	St.&nbsp;Lucie County Fire District
	Firefighters&#146; Pension Fund v. Motorola,&nbsp;Inc., et al.,
</I>
	was filed against the Company and certain current and former officers and directors of the Company on January&nbsp;21, 2010, in the United States District Court for the Northern
	District of Illinois. The complaint was amended on June&nbsp;11, 2010, and again on December&nbsp;3, 2010. The alleged class included purchasers of Motorola securities between October&nbsp;25, 2007 and January&nbsp;23, 2008. The complaint alleged
	violations of Section&nbsp;10(b) and Rule&nbsp;10b-5 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as well as, in the case of the individual defendants, the control person provisions of the Securities Exchange Act. The primary factual allegations were
	that the defendants
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage26"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280303D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	24
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	knowingly or recklessly made materially misleading statements concerning Motorola&#146;s financial projections and sales demand for Motorola phones during the class period. The complaint sought
	unspecified damages and other relief relating to the purported inflation in the price of Motorola shares during the class period. On February&nbsp;28, 2011, the Court granted defendants&#146; motion to dismiss and dismissed the Second Amended
	Complaint in its entirety with prejudice. The related derivative matter,
<I>
	Waber v. Dorman, et al.,
</I>
	was likewise dismissed with prejudice, and no appeal was taken. Plaintiffs in the
<I>
	St. Lucie
</I>
	matter subsequently filed a notice of appeal
	with the Seventh Circuit United States Court of Appeals. While the appeal was pending, the parties reached a settlement following mediation with a Court-appointed mediator. On November&nbsp;2, 2011, the District Court granted final approval of the
	settlement, entered final judgment, and dismissed the case.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Groussman&nbsp;et al. v. Motorola&nbsp;ERISA Class Action Cases
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Two purported class action lawsuits on behalf of all participants in or beneficiaries of the Motorola 401(k) Plan (the
	&#147;Plan&#148;) between July&nbsp;1, 2007 and the present and whose accounts included investments in Motorola stock,
<I>
	Joe&nbsp;M. Groussman v. Motorola, Inc. et al
</I>
	. and
<I>
	Angelo&nbsp;W. Orlando v. Motorola, Inc. et al
</I>
	., were filed
	against the Company and certain current and former officers, directors, and employees of the Company, the Motorola 401(k) Plan Committee, the Advisory Committee of Motorola and other unnamed defendants on February&nbsp;10, 2010, in the United States
	District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. On May&nbsp;20, 2010, the court ordered the cases to be consolidated. On July&nbsp;16, 2010, the plaintiffs filed a consolidated amended complaint. The amended complaint added as defendants
	additional current and former employees, the Compensation and Leadership Committee of Motorola, and the Motorola Retirement Benefits Committee, and deleted the Advisory Committee of Motorola as a defendant. The amended complaint also reduced the
	class period to run from July&nbsp;1, 2007 to December&nbsp;31, 2008. The consolidated amended complaint alleges violations of Sections&nbsp;404 and 405 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (&#147;ERISA&#148;). The primary claims
	in the amended complaint are that, in connection with alleged incorrect statements concerning Motorola&#146;s financial projections and demand for Motorola phones during the class period, various of the defendants failed to prudently and loyally
	manage the Plan by continuing to offer Motorola stock as a Plan investment option, failed to provide complete and accurate information regarding the performance of Motorola stock to the Plan&#146;s participants and beneficiaries, failed to avoid
	conflicts of interest, and/or failed to monitor the Plan fiduciaries. The amended complaint seeks unspecified damages and other relief relating to purported losses to the Plan and individual participant accounts. On September&nbsp;24, 2010, the
	Defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss the Amended Complaint. On October&nbsp;7, 2010, the court dismissed the Retirement Benefits Committee as a defendant. On January&nbsp;18, 2011, the Court denied Defendants&#146; Motion to Dismiss the Amended
	Complaint. On March&nbsp;14, 2011, Plaintiffs filed a Motion for Class Certification, seeking certification of a class of &#147;all persons who were participants in, or beneficiaries of, the Motorola 401(k) Plan at any time between July&nbsp;1, 2007
	and December&nbsp;31, 2008, and whose accounts included investments in Motorola stock&#148;, but excluding Defendants, members of their immediate families, any officer, director or partner of any Defendant, any entity in which a Defendant has a
	controlling interest, and the heirs, successors and assigns of the foregoing. On November&nbsp;15, 2011, the court denied Plaintiffs&#146; motion for class certification and the Plaintiffs have not appealed that ruling. In ruling on the
	Defendants&#146; motion to strike certain allegations in the Amended Complaint pertaining to claims &#147;on behalf of the Plan&#148;, the court subsequently confirmed that this action is now brought only on behalf of individual named plaintiff s.
	Given that limitation, we do not believe the proceedings to be material to Motorola Solutions.&nbsp;Accordingly, we will no longer be reporting on this matter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Microsoft Corporation v. Motorola,&nbsp;Inc.
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;1,
	2010, Microsoft Corporation (&#147;Microsoft&#148;) filed complaints against Motorola, Inc. in the United States International Trade Commission (&#147;ITC&#148;) and the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
	(&#147;District Court&#148;) alleging patent infringement based on products manufactured and sold by Motorola, Inc. The ITC matter is entitled
<I>
	In the Matter of Mobile Devices, Associated Software, and Components Thereof
</I>
	(Inv.
	No.&nbsp;337-TA-744). On October&nbsp;6, 2010 and October&nbsp;12, 2010, Microsoft amended the District Court and ITC complaints, respectively, to add Motorola Mobility, Inc. as a defendant. The complaints, as amended, allege infringement of claims
	of nine patents based on Motorola, Inc.&#146;s and Motorola Mobility, Inc.&#146;s manufacture, sale and/or importation of Android-based mobile phones. The ITC complaint seeks exclusion and cease and desist orders. On November&nbsp;5, 2010, the ITC
	instituted the investigation. The District Court complaint (No. C10-01577) seeks unspecified monetary damages and injunctive relief.
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280303D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX">

<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1PX SOLID #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-TOP:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	25
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On November&nbsp;9, 2010, Microsoft filed a complaint in the United States District Court
	for the Western District of Washington (No. C10-01823) against Motorola, Inc. and Motorola Mobility, Inc. (the &#147;Motorola Defendants&#148;) alleging that the Motorola Defendants breached a contractual obligation to license certain patents
	related to 802.11 wireless networking technology and H.264 video coding technology on reasonable and non-discriminatory terms and conditions. The complaint seeks unspecified monetary damages and injunctive relief including a declaration that the
	Motorola Defendants have not offered licenses to these patents to Microsoft under reasonable royalty rates, with terms and conditions that are demonstrably free of any unfair discrimination. On February&nbsp;23, 2011, Microsoft amended the complaint
	to add General Instrument Corporation as a defendant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In November 2010, Motorola Mobility, Inc. and General Instrument
	Corporation filed complaints against Microsoft in the ITC and in the U.S. District Courts for the Southern District of Florida,
<I>
	Motorola Mobility, Inc. v. Microsoft Corporation
</I>
	and the Western District of Wisconsin,
<I>
	Motorola Mobility, Inc.
	and General Instrument Corporation v. Microsoft Corporation
</I>
	(No. 10-cv-699) and
<I>
	Motorola Mobility, Inc. and General Instrument Corporation v. Microsoft Corporation
</I>
	(No. 10-cv-700). The ITC matter is entitled
<I>
	In the Matter of Certain
	Gaming and Entertainment Consoles, Related Software, and Components Thereof
</I>
	(Inv.&nbsp;No.&nbsp;337-TA-752). Among the complaints, Motorola Mobility, Inc. and General Instrument Corporation are asserting infringement of claims of sixteen patents
	by Microsoft&#146;s PC and Server software, Windows mobile and smartphone software and Xbox products. The ITC complaint seeks exclusion and cease and desist orders directed to these products. On December&nbsp;23, 2010, the ITC instituted the
	investigation. The District Court complaints seek monetary damages and injunctive relief. In December 2010 and February 2011, Motorola Mobility, Inc. subsequently asserted claims of five additional patents in the Western District of Wisconsin,
<I>
	Motorola Mobility, Inc. v. Microsoft Corporation
</I>
	(No. 10-cv-826). Between December&nbsp;23, 2010 and January&nbsp;25, 2011, Microsoft filed counterclaims against Motorola Mobility, Inc. in several of these actions, alleging infringement of a
	total of fourteen additional Microsoft patents. Two of the complaints filed by Motorola Mobility, Inc. and General Instrument Corporation in the Western District of Wisconsin have been transferred to the Western District of Washington.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In late June 2011 Motorola Solutions, Inc., Motorola Mobility, Inc. and Microsoft Corporation filed a joint motion to remove Motorola
	Solutions, Inc. as a respondent in the ITC matter. That motion was subsequently approved by the Commission in early July 2011. As a result, Motorola Solutions, Inc. is no longer a participant in the ITC matter except with regard to the production of
	certain information dating from prior to January&nbsp;4, 2011. Motorola Solutions, Inc. will not be bound by any remedy granted by the ITC, such as an exclusion order, unless Motorola Solutions, Inc. is importing and/or reselling products made by
	Motorola Mobility, Inc. Although Motorola Solutions, Inc. remains a party to certain of the complaints filed in district courts referenced above, no Motorola Solutions products are subject to the matters and we do not believe the proceedings to be
	material to Motorola Solutions. Accordingly, we will no longer be reporting on these matters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<I>
	Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. v.
	Apple&nbsp;Inc.
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;6, 2010, Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. filed a complaint for patent infringement
	against Apple&nbsp;Inc. with the ITC. The matter is entitled
<I>
	In the Matter of Certain Wireless Communication Devices, Portable Music and Data Processing Devices, Computers and Components Thereof
</I>
	(Inv. No.&nbsp;337-TA-745). On November&nbsp;8,
	2010, the ITC instituted the investigation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;6, 2010, Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. filed a complaint for patent
	infringement against Apple&nbsp;Inc. in
<I>
	Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. v Apple Inc.,
</I>
	in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida (the &#147;Florida Complaint&#148;). On November&nbsp;18, 2010, Apple counterclaimed
	in the Southern District of Florida, alleging infringement of six Apple patents by both Motorola, Inc&#146;s and Motorola Mobility, Inc.&#146;s manufacture and sale of mobile devices, set-top boxes and digital video recorders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;8, 2010, Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. filed a complaint for declaratory relief against Apple&nbsp;Inc. and NeXT
	Software,&nbsp;Inc. in
<I>
	Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. v. Apple&nbsp;Inc. and NeXT Software, Inc.,
</I>
	in the United States District Court for the District of Delaware. The complaint seeks a judgment declaring that Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. has
	not infringed, induced the infringement of, or contributed to the infringement of any valid, enforceable claim of twelve patents owned by Apple&nbsp;Inc. and NeXT Software,&nbsp;Inc. On December&nbsp;2, 2010, Apple asserted these twelve patents
	against Motorola, Inc. and Motorola Mobility, Inc. in the Western District of Wisconsin, seeking to transfer the Delaware action to Wisconsin.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;29, 2010, Apple&nbsp;Inc. filed two complaints for patent infringement against Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. in
<I>
	Apple&nbsp;Inc. v. Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and
	Motorola Mobility, Inc.,
</I>
	in the United States District
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280303D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	26
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Court for the Western District of Wisconsin. The complaints allege infringement of six patents by Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. The complaints allege that
	Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. directly infringes, contributorily infringes and/or induces others to infringe the patents-in-suit by making, using, offering for sale and selling in the United States certain mobile devices and
	related software. The complaint seeks unspecified monetary damages and injunctive relief. On November&nbsp;9, 2010, Motorola Mobility, Inc. filed counterclaims against Apple Inc. to their complaints alleging infringement of twelve Motorola Mobility,
	Inc. patents.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;29, 2010, Apple&nbsp;Inc. filed a complaint alleging patent infringement against
	Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. with the United States International Trade Commission. The matter is entitled
<I>
	In the Matter of Certain Mobile Devices and Related Software
</I>
	(Inv. No.&nbsp;337-TA-750). The complaint alleges
	infringement of three patents by Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. The complaint alleges that Motorola,&nbsp;Inc. and Motorola Mobility,&nbsp;Inc. directly infringe, contributorily infringe and/or induce others to infringe the
	three patents by manufacturing, marketing and selling in the United States mobile devices, such as smartphones, and associated software, including operating systems, user interfaces, and other application software designed for use on, and loaded
	onto, such devices. The complaint seeks the issuance of an exclusion order barring from entry into the United States certain mobile devices and related software and a cease and desist order prohibiting Motorola, Inc. (now Motorola Solutions, Inc.)
	and Motorola Mobility, Inc. from importing, selling, transporting, and other related activities of certain mobile devices and related software. On November&nbsp;30, 2010, the ITC instituted the investigation. On July&nbsp;27, 2011 Motorola
	Solutions, Inc. filed an unopposed motion to remove Motorola Solutions, Inc. as a respondent in the ITC matter.&nbsp;The motion was subsequently approved by the Commission on August&nbsp;15, 2011.&nbsp;As a result, Motorola Solutions, Inc. is no
	longer a participant in the ITC matter. Although Motorola Solutions, Inc. remains a party to certain of the complaints filed in district courts referenced above, no Motorola Solutions products are subject to the matters and we do not believe the
	proceedings to be material to Motorola Solutions. Accordingly, we will no longer be reporting on these matters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Company is
	a defendant in various other suits, claims and investigations that arise in the normal course of business. In the opinion of management, the ultimate disposition of the Company&#146;s pending legal proceedings will not have a material adverse effect
	on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, liquidity or results of operations. However, an unfavorable resolution could have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, liquidity or results of
	operations in the periods in which the matters are ultimately resolved.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_LEGAL_PROCEEDINGS>
<EFX_MINE_SAFETY_DISCLOSURE>
<A NAME="FIS_MINE_SAFETY_DISCLOSURE"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
<A NAME="D280303D10K_HTM_TOC280303_21">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;4: Mine Safety Disclosures
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Not applicable.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D280303D10K_HTM_TOC280303_22">
</A>
	Executive Officers of the Registrant
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Following are the persons who were the executive officers of Motorola Solutions as of February&nbsp;14, 2012, their ages as of
	January&nbsp;1, 2012, their current titles and positions they have held during the last five years:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Gregory Q. Brown; age 51;
	Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, since May&nbsp;3, 2011; President and Chief Executive Officer from January 2011 to May 2011; Co-Chief Executive Officer, Motorola, Inc. and Chief Executive Officer of Broadband Mobility Solutions from August
	2008 to January 2011; President and Chief Executive Officer from January 2008 to August 2008; President and Chief Operating Officer from June 2007 to January 2008; Executive Vice President, President, Networks and Enterprise from June 2006 to June
	2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Michael D. Annes; age 48; Senior Vice President, Business Development and Ventures since July&nbsp;26, 2011; Corporate
	Vice President, Business Development and Ventures, Motorola Solutions, Inc. from January 2011 to July 2011; Corporate Vice President, Business Development and Ventures, Motorola, Inc. from January 2009 to January 2011; Corporate Vice President, Law,
	Integrated Supply Chain from February 2005 to January 2009.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Michele A. Carlin; age 50; Senior Vice President, Human Resources
	since January&nbsp;4, 2011; Senior Vice President, Human Resources, Motorola, Inc. from November 2009 to January 2011; Corporate Vice President, Human Resources, Global Rewards and HR Shared Services from July 2008 to October 2009; Vice President,
	Global Compensation, Benefits&nbsp;&amp; HR Technology, Campbell Soup Company from June 2006 to July 2008.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Eduardo F. Conrado;
	age 45; Senior Vice President, Chief Marketing Officer since January&nbsp;4, 2011; Senior Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer, Motorola Solutions, Motorola, Inc. from September 2010 to January 2011; Senior Vice President, Chief Marketing
	Officer, Enterprise Mobility Solutions and Home&nbsp;&amp; Networks business from March 2009 to September 2010; Corporate Vice President, Marketing and Communications, Home and Networks Mobility Business from December 2007 to March 2009; Vice
	President, Global Marketing and Communications, Networks&nbsp;&amp; Enterprise businesses from January 2006 to December 2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Eugene A. Delaney; age 55; Executive Vice President, Product and Business Operations since January&nbsp;4, 2011; Executive Vice President,
	Product and Business Operations, Enterprise Mobility Solutions, Motorola, Inc. from August 2010 to January 2011; Executive Vice President, President, Enterprise Mobility Solutions from January 2009 to August 2010; Senior Vice President, Government
	and Public Safety from May 2007 to January 2009; Senior Vice President, International Sales Operations, Networks and Enterprise from May 2006 to May 2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Edward J. Fitzpatrick; age 45; Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer since May&nbsp;3, 2011; Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer from January 2011 to May 2011; Senior Vice
	President, Chief Financial Officer, Motorola, Inc. from October 2009 to January 2011; Senior Vice President, Corporate Controller and Acting Chief Financial Officer from February 2009 to October 2009; Senior Vice President and Corporate Controller
	from January 2009 to February 2009; Corporate Vice President, Finance, Home and Networks Mobility from January 2008 to January 2009; Vice President, Finance, Home and Networks Mobility from June 2007 to January 2008; Vice President, Finance and
	Controller, Networks and Enterprise from April 2006 to June 2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Mark F. Moon; age 48; Executive Vice President, Sales and
	Field Operations since May&nbsp;3, 2011; Senior Vice President, Sales and Field Operations from January 2011 to May 2011; Senior Vice President, Sales and Field Operations, Motorola Solutions, Motorola, Inc. from August 2010 to January 2011; Senior
	Vice President, Worldwide Field Operations, Enterprise Mobility Solutions business from April 2009 to August 2010
<B>
	;
</B>
	Senior Vice President, Government and Commercial Markets&#151;Americas, ASTRO Product Management, Enterprise Mobility Solutions
	Business from January 2008 to April 2009; Senior Vice President, NA and LAC Biometrics, ASTRO, PCR Product Management, Government and Public Safety Business, Enterprise Mobility Solutions Group from July 2007 to January 2008; Senior Vice President,
	North America Government and Commercial Markets, Networks and Enterprise Business from December 2006 to July 2007.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Lewis A.
	Steverson; age 48; Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary to the Board since January&nbsp;4, 2011; Senior Vice President and General Counsel, Motorola Solutions, Motorola, Inc., from August 2010 to January 2011; Senior Vice President,
	Law, Enterprise Mobility Solutions business from April 2010 to August 2010; Corporate Vice President, Law, Broadband Mobility business from May 2007 to April 2010; Corporate Vice President, Law, Networks&nbsp;&amp; Enterprise business from March
	2006 to May 2007.
</FONT>
</P>

<EFX_MARKET>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
<A NAME="D280303D10K_HTM_TOC280303_24">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;5: Market for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity
	Securities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Motorola Solutions common stock is listed on the New York and Chicago Stock Exchanges. The number of
	stockholders of record of Motorola Solutions common stock on January&nbsp;31, 2012 was 54,119.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Information regarding
	securities authorized for issuance under equity compensation plans is incorporated by reference to the information under the caption &#147;Equity Compensation Plan Information&#148; of Motorola Solutions&#146; Proxy Statement for the 2011 Annual
	Meeting of Stockholders. The remainder of the response to this Item incorporates by reference Note&nbsp;16, &#147;Quarterly and Other Financial Data (unaudited)&#148; of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements appearing under
	&#147;Item&nbsp;8: Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.&#148;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table provides information with respect to
	acquisitions by the Company of shares of its common stock during the quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	PERFORMANCE GRAPH
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following graph compares the five-year cumulative total returns of Motorola Solutions,&nbsp;Inc., the S&amp;P&nbsp;500 Index and the
	S&amp;P Communications Equipment Index.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	This graph assumes $100 was invested in the stock or the Index on December&nbsp;31,
	2006 and also assumes the reinvestment of dividends, including the Company&#146;s distribution to its shareholders of one share of Motorola Mobility for every eight shares of Motorola, Inc. common stock on January&nbsp;4, 2011. For purposes of this
	graph, the Motorola Mobility distribution is treated as a non-taxable cash dividend of $26.46 (per share post reverse stock split) that would have been reinvested in Motorola Solutions common stock at the close of business January&nbsp;4, 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2012/02/15/0001193125-12-063569_G280303G58Q72.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
</P>
<P>
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

<EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<A NAME="FIS_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
<A NAME="D280303D10K_HTM_TOC280303_26">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7: Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition
	and Results of Operations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a discussion and analysis of our financial position and results of operations
	for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2011. This commentary should be read in conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and the notes thereto appearing under &#147;Item&nbsp;8: Financial Statements and
	Supplementary Data.&#148;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
	Executive Overview
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	What businesses are we in?
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We report financial results for two operating
	segments:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:8%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Government:
</B>
	Our Government segment includes sales of public safety mission-critical communication systems,
	commercial two-way radio systems and devices, software and services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:8%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Enterprise:
</B>
	Our Enterprise segment includes sales
	of rugged and enterprise-grade mobile computers and tablets, laser/imaging/RFID based data capture products, WLAN and iDEN infrastructure, software and services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	What were our 2011 financial results?
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We increased net sales by 8% to $8.2 billion&nbsp;in 2011, compared to net sales of $7.6 billion in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We generated operating earnings of $858 million in 2011, compared to $751 million in 2010. Operating margin was 10.5% of net sales in 2011, compared to
	9.9% of net sales in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We had earnings from continuing operations of $747 million, or $2.20 per diluted common share, in 2011, compared to earnings from continuing operations
	of $244 million, or $0.72 per diluted common share, in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We generated cash from operating activities of $848 million in 2011, compared to $803 million of cash from operating activities in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We returned $1.1 billion in cash to shareholders through share repurchases and paid $72 million in cash dividends during 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We used approximately $1.2 billion to retire long-term debt.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	What were the financial results for our two operating segments in 2011?
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	In our Government segment:
</I>
	Net sales were $5.4 billion in 2011, an increase of 6% compared to net sales of $5.0 billion in 2010. On a geographic
	basis, net sales increased in North America, Latin America, and Asia, while Europe, Middle East and Africa region (&#147;EMEA&#148;) was down slightly due to the sale of the Israel-based module business in the first quarter of 2011. Operating margin
	improved in 2011 to 11.5% from 10.6% in 2010 primarily due to increased leverage in SG&amp;A expenses and R&amp;D expenditures. Operating earnings were $616 million in 2011, compared to operating earnings of $534 million in 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	In our Enterprise segment:
</I>
	Net sales were $2.8 billion in 2011, an increase of 11% compared to net sales of $2.6 billion in 2010. On a
	geographic basis, net sales increased in all regions. Operating earnings were $242 million in 2011, compared to operating earnings of $217 million in 2010. Operating margin remained flat in 2011 compared to 2010 as a result of increased expenses
	recorded in Other charges, offset by increased leverage in SG&amp;A expenses and R&amp;D expenditures.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	What were our
	major accomplishments in 2011?
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	In our Government segment:
</I>
	In 2011, sales, operating earnings, and operating leverage were higher than in 2010. Despite the budget challenges
	facing many of the U.S. government customers and in parts of Western Europe, our customers continue to prioritize funding of their public safety communication needs, and demand for our products and solutions in the government and public safety
	market increased as compared to 2010. In 2011, our continued commitment to quality, enhancements to our comprehensive portfolio, and a strong customer base contributed to higher sales to our U.S. government customers.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D280303D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="96%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" STYLE="BORDER-TOP:1PX SOLID #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-RIGHT:8PX" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	33
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:6%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of our continued strong commitment to R&amp;D, the year brought many new
	enhancements to our product portfolio. We expanded our APX&#153; lineup of radio&#146;s to include an APX4000 portable radio for public works, utilities, and rural public safety. APX now represents the first complete portfolio of P25 Phase 2 TDMA
	two-way portable radios in the industry. We continued our investment in our next-generation public safety LTE solutions and achieved another milestone with the first commercial shipment of our public safety LTE devices. Growth in our
	&#147;professional and commercial&#148; product portfolio continued this year driven by customers replacing analog systems with digital using our MOTOTRBO platform.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	In our Enterprise segment:
</I>
	Our 2011 sales growth was primarily due to improved demand within the retail and transportation and logistics
	markets, as a result of our customers continuing to invest in technology to drive sales growth and improved productivity.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:6%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our R&amp;D investments resulted in many new enhancements to our product portfolio. We continued our investment in next generation technologies like the ET1 tablet, the first in an emerging category of
	enterprise-class tablet computers designed for verticals like retail, manufacturing, and logistics. Additionally, we expanded our mobile computing portfolio with the MC2100 industrial series, addressing the need for a smaller, rugged enterprise
	mobile computer that expands the range of solutions available for large enterprises and small- and medium-sized businesses. This is the first value-tier rugged handheld in the industry to support HTML5 via the RhoElements application framework we
	introduced in 2011.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="3">
<B>
	Looking Forward
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Although the government budget environment remains challenging in the U.S. and in parts of Western Europe in particular, there continue to be signs of improvement.&nbsp;Our customers continue to
	prioritize funding of their public safety communication needs, and we remain focused on helping them find ways to fund system upgrades, improve interoperability and meet spectrum narrow-banding requirements.&nbsp;In addition, governments continue to
	examine their operations for the productivity and efficiency improvements that our products and services enable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Private
	public safety broadband networks based on the LTE standard are an important next generation tool for our first-responder customers. The 700 Mhz D-block spectrum would efficiently and effectively double the spectrum available for public safety grade
	broadband data networks. We have been investing in R&amp;D for next generation public safety, and our expertise in both public and private networks makes us uniquely qualified to provide LTE solutions.&nbsp;The development of this market is an
	important part of our overall global growth strategy for the Government segment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Our Enterprise segment continued strong sales
	growth in 2011 from improvements in retail spending resulting in an increased demand trend as many of our customers reinvested in technology to improve supply chain efficiencies, increase productivity of associates and improve end-customer buying
	experiences. We believe the trend of increased mobile workers, and demand for real-time information will accelerate next-generation enterprise mobile computing and advanced data capture solutions. Our solutions have a high return on investment, and
	with increasing demands for real-time information, and rapid increases in knowledge workers, we expect continued sales growth.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For the iDEN infrastructure business, which we report in the Enterprise segment, we expect to see a continued decline in iDEN
	infrastructure and related services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2011, we announced the creation of a global services organization. We have expanded
	our current services offerings by bringing deep customer insight and expertise with an intense focus on our core markets through every step of the solution lifecycle. From our industry expertise to our channel partner community, we believe we are
	uniquely positioned to provide our Government and Enterprise customers the products and services they require to meet their mobile workforce needs, and build successful long-term relationships.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We are committed to employing disciplined financial policies, achieving our financial plan, and executing on our capital allocation
	framework. In 2012, we intend to continue the quarterly dividends that were initiated in 2011 and will continue to invest organically in capital expenditures. We will also continue to evaluate our acquisition opportunities along with the
	opportunities to return capital to shareholders via share repurchases. On July&nbsp;28, 2011, we announced that our Board of Directors approved a share repurchase program that allows us to purchase up to $2.0 billion of our outstanding common stock
	through December&nbsp;31, 2012. Additionally, on January&nbsp;30, 2011, we announced that our Board of Directors approved up to $1.0 billion in additional funds for use under the existing share repurchase program through the end of 2012.
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

	&nbsp;

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">

<TD WIDTH="96%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ROWSPAN="2" NOWRAP STYLE="BORDER:1PX SOLID #000000; PADDING-LEFT:8PX" BGCOLOR="#E5E5E5">
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;34&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We conduct our business in competitive markets, facing both new and established competitors.
	The markets for many of our products are characterized by rapidly changing technologies and evolving industry standards. Market disruptions caused by new technologies, the entry of new competitors, consolidations among our customers and competitors,
	and changes in regulatory requirements, among other matters, can introduce volatility into our businesses. Meeting all of these challenges requires consistent operational planning and execution and investment in technology, resulting in innovative
	products that meet the needs of our customers globally. As we execute on meeting these objectives, we remain focused on taking the necessary action to design and deliver differentiated and innovative products and services that serve the needs of our
	Government and Enterprise segments.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Results of Operations&#151;2011 Compared to 2010
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Net Sales
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net sales were $8.2 billion in 2011, an 8% increase compared to
	net sales of $7.6 billion in 2010. The increase in net sales reflects: (i)&nbsp;a $309 million, or 6%, increase in net sales in the Government segment, and (ii)&nbsp;a $277 million, or 11%, increase in net sales in the Enterprise segment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Gross Margin
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Gross margin was $4.1 billion, or 50.5% of net sales in 2011, compared to $3.8 billion, or 50.0% of net sales, in 2010. Gross margin
	dollars increased in both segments. The increase in gross margin reflects higher gross margin in the Government segment, with margins remaining flat in the Enterprise segment. The increase in the Government segment was primarily driven by the
	increase in net sales and product mix, while the Enterprise segment had margin gains in certain product lines offset by the anticipated decline in iDEN, which has historically yielded strong margins.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Selling, general and administrative (&#147;SG&amp;A&#148;) expenses increased 2% to $1.9 billion, or 23.2% of net sales, in 2011, compared to $1.9 billion, or 24.5% of net sales, in 2010. SG&amp;A
	expenses as a percentage of net sales decreased in both segments. The increase in SG&amp;A expenses reflects higher SG&amp;A expenses in both segments, primarily due to (i)&nbsp;increased sales incentives related to the increase in net sales, and
	(ii)&nbsp;increased employee benefit-related expenses. The increases in employee benefit-related expenses are primarily due to an increase in pension-related expenses and the reinstatement of our 401(k) matching contributions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Research and Development Expenditures
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Research and development (&#147;R&amp;D&#148;) expenditures of $1.0 billion, or 12.6% of net sales were relatively flat, in 2011, compared to $1.0 billion, or 13.6% of net sales, in 2010. R&amp;D
	expenditures as a percentage of net sales decreased in both segments. R&amp;D expenditures were flat in 2011 compared to 2010, which reflects higher R&amp;D expenditures in the Enterprise segment and lower R&amp;D expenditures in the Government
	segment. The slight increase in the Enterprise segment was primarily due to investment in next-generation technologies and increased employee benefit-related expenses. The decrease in R&amp;D expenditures in the Government segment was primarily due
	to savings from cost reduction initiatives related to non employee related expenditures, partially offset by increased employee benefit expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Other Charges
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We recorded net charges of $341 million in Other charges in
	2011, compared to net charges of $150 million in 2010. The charges in 2011 included: (i)&nbsp;$200 million of charges relating to the amortization of intangibles, (ii)&nbsp;$88 million of net charges relating to legal matters, (iii)&nbsp;$52 million
	of net reorganization of business charges and, (iv)&nbsp;$10 million related to a long term financing receivable reserve, partially offset by $9 million of net gains from pension plan adjustments. The charges in 2010 included: (i)&nbsp;$203 million
	of charges relating to the amortization of intangibles, and (ii)&nbsp;$54 million of net reorganization of business charges, partially offset by: (i)&nbsp;$78 million of gains related to intellectual property settlements and reserve adjustments, and
	(ii)&nbsp;$29 million of income related to a legal settlement. The net reorganization of business charges are discussed in further detail in the &#147;Reorganization of Businesses&#148; section.
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;36&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:1PX" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>

<TR STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1PX">
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Net Interest Expense
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net interest expense was $74 million in 2011, compared to net interest expense of $129 million in 2010. Net interest expense in 2011 included interest expense of $132 million, partially offset by interest
	income of $58 million. Net interest expense in 2010 includes interest expense of $217 million, partially offset by interest income of $88 million. The decrease in net interest expense is primarily attributable to lower interest expense driven by
	lower average debt outstanding partially offset by lower interest income driven by lower average cash and cash equivalents and lower yields during 2011 compared to 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Gains on Sales of Investments and Businesses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Gains on sales of investments
	and businesses were $23 million in 2011, compared to a gain of $49 million in 2010. In 2011, the net gain was primarily comprised of gains related to sales of certain of our equity investments. In 2010, the net gain was primarily comprised of a gain
	on the sale of a single investment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Other
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net Other expense was $69 million in 2011, compared to net Other expense of $7 million in 2010. The net Other expense in 2011 was primarily comprised of an $81 million loss from the extinguishment of a
	portion of our outstanding long-term debt, partially offset by an $8 million foreign currency gain. The net expense in 2010 was primarily comprised of: (i)&nbsp;$21 million of investment impairments, and (ii)&nbsp;a $12 million loss from the
	extinguishment of a portion of our outstanding long-term debt, partially offset by: (i)&nbsp;a $12 million foreign currency gain, and (ii)&nbsp;an $11 million gain from Sigma Fund investments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Effective Tax Rate
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We
	recorded $3 million of net tax benefit in 2011, resulting in a negative effective tax rate on continuing operations compared to $403 million of net tax expense in 2010, resulting in an effective tax rate of 61%. Our negative effective tax rate in
	2011 was primarily due to: (i)&nbsp;a $274 million tax benefit related to the reversal of a significant portion of the valuation allowance established on the U.S. deferred tax assets, and (ii)&nbsp;reductions in unrecognized tax benefits for facts
	that now indicate the extent to which certain tax positions are more-likely-than-not of being sustained, partially offset by an increase in the U.S. federal income tax accrual for repatriation of undistributed foreign earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The valuation allowances on our deferred tax assets are discussed further in Note 6, &#147;Income Taxes,&#148; of our consolidated
	financial statements. Our effective tax rate will change from period to period based on non-recurring events, such as the settlement of income tax audits, changes in valuation allowances and the tax impact of significant unusual or extraordinary
	items, as well as recurring factors including changes in the geographic mix of income and effects of various global income tax strategies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Earnings from Continuing Operations
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	After taxes, and excluding earnings attributable to noncontrolling interests, we had net earnings from continuing operations of $747 million, or $2.20 per diluted share, in 2011, compared to $244 million,
	or $0.72 per diluted share, in 2010. The improvement in the earnings from continuing operations in 2011 compared to 2010 was primarily attributable to a $334 million increase in gross margin and a $406 million decrease in tax expense. These
	improvements were partially offset by a $191 million increase in other charges, and a $38 million increase in SG&amp;A expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Earnings
	(loss) from Discontinued Operations
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; TEXT-INDENT:4%">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	After taxes, we had earnings from discontinued operations of $411 million, or $1.21
	per diluted share, in 2011, compared to earnings from discontinued operations of $389 million, or $1.15 per diluted share, in 2010. The earnings from discontinued operations in 2011 was primarily from the operations and gain from the sale of the
	Networks business. The earnings from discontinued operations in 2010 were primarily from the Networks business, partially offset by losses from Motorola Mobility.
</FONT>
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
